(Sec. 1253) Directs the President to direct the U.S. Permanent Representative to the United Nations to oppose the creation of any new or expansion of any existing U.N. peacekeeping operation until the Secretary certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that specified reforms have been implemented, including: (1) adoption of a uniform code of conduct and related training mechanisms; (2) design of educational outreach programs within local communities to explain prohibited acts and identify the individual to whom the local population may direct complaints of misconduct; (3) creation of a centralized database to track cases of misconduct; (4) establishment of an independent investigative and audit function; and (5) adoption of a model memorandum of understanding for troop contributing countries. (Sec. 1254) States that nothing in this title shall be: (1) construed as superseding the Uniform Code of Military Justice or operating to effect the surrender of U.S. officials or members of the armed forces to a foreign country or international tribunal, including the International Criminal Court, for prosecutions arising from peacekeeping operations or other similar U.N. activity; and (2) interpreted in a manner inconsistent with the American Servicemembers' Protection Act of 2002. Subtitle E: Department of State and Government Accountability Office - (Sec. 1261) Directs the Secretary to make every effort to recruit U.S. citizens for positions in international organizations. (Sec. 1262) Requires the annual congressional budget justification to include an itemized request in support of the assessed U.S. contribution to the U.N. regular assessed budget. States that: (1) such itemization shall contain information relating to the amounts in support of each section and title of the regular assessed budget, and compare such amounts with previous U.S. contributions; and (2) the Secretary shall consult with the appropriate congressional committees respecting any proposed U.N. budget adjustments. (Sec. 1263) Directs the Secretary report to the appropriate congressional committees with respect to U.N. programs that are funded through assessed contributions, including recommendations concerning which programs should be continued and which should be voluntarily funded. (Sec. 1264) Directs GAO to report respecting: (1) the status of the management reforms recommended by the Secretary General in 1997, 2002, and 2005; (2) certifications required by this Act and the United Nations Participation Act of 1945; and (3) construction costs for the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) buildings in Geneva, Switzerland. Subtitle F: Certifications and Withholding of Contributions - (Sec. 1271) States that if the budgeting, oversight and accountability, and human rights certifications (or the alternative certifications) required by this Act are not implemented the United States shall appropriate but withhold 50% of its contributions to the U.N. regular assessed budget. Requires: (1) certifications for 2007 and subsequent years; and (2) annual compliance reviews by the Secretary, and reapplication of the 50% withholding for subsequent certification noncompliance. Sets forth an alternative certification process under which the Secretary may certify to the appropriate congressional committees that the requirements for each certification have been implemented through reforms that are substantially similar or accomplish the same purposes (as defined by this Act). States that: (1) if at least 32 of the reforms have been implemented all reforms shall be considered to have been implemented for the year of certification; and (2) if the remaining reforms have not been implemented by the next year the 50% withholding provision shall apply. Specifies 15 reforms required to be among such 32 reforms, including: (1) 20% reductions for Public Information and General Assembly Affairs and Conference Services budgets; (2) annual budget level maintenance; (3) new program sunset provisions; (4) an Independent Oversight Board; (5) a United Nations Office of Ethics; (6) U.N. human rights body ineligibility for a member country failing to uphold the values of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, or under Security Council sanction or investigation for human rights abuses; (7) barring any U.N. human rights body from having a standing agenda item that relates only to one country or region; (8) Economic and Social Council secret voting abolishment; and (9) Commission on Human Rights membership. Title XIII: Opening Doors for Foreign Students - Opening Doors for Foreign Students Act of 2005 - (Sec. 1303) Directs the Secretary to develop and report to the appropriate congressional committees on a comprehensive strategy to attract foreign students to study in the United States. (Sec. 1304) Directs the The Secretary to: (1) review the five-year application and issuance rates for F-1 (foreign student) and J-1 (exchange visitor) nonimmigrant visas at U.S. diplomatic or consular missions, identify missions that have experienced significant application and visa issuance declines and missions that have experienced subsequent recovery rates; (2) obtain best practices from those missions that have experienced recoveries and direct those missions that have experienced declines to apply corrective measures; and (3) report to the appropriate congressional committees. (Sec. 1305) Amends the Foreign Service Act of 1980 to direct the Secretary to establish Foreign Service training in processing F-1 and J-1 visas. (Sec. 1306) States that the Secretary should undertake a diplomatic dialogue with key foreign governments, including the PRC and the Russian Federation, to provide for extended validity of F-1 and J-1 visas. Title XIV: Miscellaneous Provisions - Subtitle A: General Provisions - (Sec. 1401) States that it is U.S. policy that: (1) there is not a free and fully democratic government in Iran; (2) the United States supports full democracy in Iran; (3) the United States supports the rights of the Iranian people to choose their system of government; and (4) the United States condemns the brutal treatment, imprisonment, and torture of Iranian political dissenters. (Sec. 1402) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) Russia's assistance to Iran on the Bushehr nuclear reactor is inconsistent with U.S. nonproliferation goals; (2) Iran's stated plans to construct 20 new nuclear facilities and its development of nuclear technologies, coupled with acknowledged and unacknowledged ties to terrorist groups, constitute a threat to global peace and security; and (3) U.S. national security interests will best be served if the United States implements a long-term strategy to halt all foreign nuclear cooperation with Iran. Calls upon the G-8 governments to: (1) insist that Russia terminate all assistance to the Bushehr nuclear facility; and (2) condition Russia's continued G-8 membership on Russia's termination of all assistance to nuclear plants in Iran. (Sec. 1403) Declares that, for the purpose of maintaining regional balances with respect to the location of international organizations and institutions in Africa, such organizations or institutions, such as the African Development Bank, that move their headquarters offices from their original locations for reasons of security should return once those security issues have been resolved or should relocate to another country in the region in which the organization or institution was originally headquartered. (Sec. 1404) Amends the the International Academic Opportunity Act of 2000 (title III of the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance and International Anti-Corruption Act of 2000) to increase the authorization level for the Benjamin Gilman International Scholarship Program. (Sec. 1405) Prohibits the Department and its missions abroad from engaging in any activity, such as the celebration of Showa holiday, which may serve to commemorate the leaders of Imperial Japan connected to the attack on the U.S. Fleet at Pearl Harbor, Oahu, Hawaii, on December 7, 1941. (Sec. 1406) Directs the Secretary to: (1) secure the support of the governments of countries represented on the decisionmaking boards and councils of the World Bank Group (the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Association, the International Financial Corporation, and the Multilateral Investment Guaranty Agency) to oppose any further activity in Iran until Iran abandons its nuclear weapons program; and (2) report to the appropriate congressional committees. (Sec. 1407) States that it is U.S. policy to support the activities of the Southeast European Cooperative Initiative (SECI) Regional Center for Combating Trans-Border Crime. (Sec. 1408) Calls on Turkey to uphold and safeguard religious and human rights, and to grant specified rights and recognition to the Ecumenical Patriarch. (Sec. 1409) Expresses appreciation for the government of Azerbaijan's efforts to find the individual(s) responsible for the murder of U.S. citizen John M. Alvis, and urges the Secretary to make this a priority issue in U.S.-Azerbaijan relations. (Sec. 1410) Condemns the disenfranchisement of women, including restrictions that prevent women from holding office. Calls on the government of Saudi Arabia to promulgate a law that grants women the rights to vote and hold office. Encourages the President to take appropriate action, including downgrading diplomatic relations, to encourage countries that disenfranchise only women to grant women such rights. (Sec. 1411) Authorizes FY2006-FY2007 appropriations for the Department's Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affair (INL) to purchase or lease a maritime refueling support vessel to support U.S. drug interdiction duties in the Eastern Pacific maritime transit zone. (Sec. 1412) States that it is U.S. policy to oppose any international or global tax that is or may be considered by the United Nations or its agencies, with an exception for publication or other fees that are not tantamount to a tax on a U.S. person. (Sec. 1413) Commends: (1) the Heads of State of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, the PRC, Russia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan) for their declaration of support of the Global War on Terrorism and for their efforts to combat and prevent terrorism; and (2) the support of the international coalition in Afghanistan. Calls on the President, the Secretary, and the Secretary of Defense to open a dialogue with SCO member states concerning base use, and report to Congress on the outcome of such dialogue. (Sec. 1414) Directs the Secretary to: (1) to take specified actions through the INL to prevent the smuggling of methamphetamine into the United States from Mexico; and (2) report annually to the appropriate congressional committees. Authorizes FY2006-FY2007 appropriations. (Sec. 1415) Condemns and enumerates the attacks on U.S. citizens by Palestinian terrorists and demands that the PA work with Israel to protect all innocent individuals, regardless of citizenship, from terrorist atrocities. Offers congressional condolences to the families of U.S. citizens killed by Palestinian terrorist attacks. (Sec. 1416) States that it shall be U.S. policy to seek the expeditious transfer of Charles Ghankay Taylor, former President of the Republic of Liberia, to the jurisdiction of the Special Court for Sierra Leone to undergo trial for war crimes, crimes against humanity, and other serious violations of international humanitarian law. (Sec. 1417) Expresses the sense of Congress that calls for an early withdrawal of U.S. and coalition forces from Iraq: (1) are counterproductive to U.S. security aims and the hopes of the Iraqi people; and (2) undermine the morale of U.S., coalition, and Iraqi forces and put their security at risk. States that it shall be U.S. policy: (1) to pursue a transfer of responsibility for Iraqi security to Iraqi forces; and (2) not to withdraw prematurely U.S. armed forces from Iraq, but to do so only when U.S. national security and foreign policy goals relating to a free and stable Iraq have been achieved. Subtitle B: Sense of Congress Provisions - (Sec. 1421) Expresses the sense of Congress that Fulbright program activities for the Republic of Korea should provide for participation by students from throughout South Korea representing a broad range of educational institutions, programs, and courses of study. (Sec. 1422) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) it is in U.S. national interests to communicate directly with officials of Taiwan, including the President of Taiwan, the Vice-President of Taiwan, the Foreign Minister of Taiwan, and the Defense Minister of Taiwan; and (2) the Department should admit such officials to the United States, and facilitate high level meetings between them and their U.S. counterparts. (Sec. 1423) Recognizes Dr. Abdul Qadeer Khan's role as a nuclear arms trafficker and China's involvement in the trafficking network by providing Dr. Khan with nuclear weapons designs. Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should: (1) continue efforts to dismantle the illegal international nuclear proliferation network created by Dr. Khan, and counter through diplomacy and negotiation the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction from Pakistan to other countries; (2) request interviews with, and Pakistan should grant access to, Dr. Khan and his top associates; and (3) take the steps necessary to ensure that Pakistan has verifiably halted any cooperation with any country in the development of nuclear or missile technology, or any other technology, material, or equipment for the development of weapons of mass destruction. (Sec 1424) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary should: (1) strongly express U.S. opposition to the inclusion in Palestinian textbooks of materials which foster anti-Semitism and rejection of peace with Israel; and (2) express U.S. unwillingness to continue to support PA educational programs should the PA continue to include material which does not foster tolerance and peace. (Sec. 1425) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should play a leading role in the drafting of an international convention that affirms the human rights and dignity of persons with disabilities; and (2) the President should authorize the Secretary to send to the Sixth Session of the United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on a Comprehensive and Integral International Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Rights and Dignity of Persons with Disabilities a U.S. delegation which includes leaders in the U.S. disability rights movement. (Sec. 1426) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Department should report to the appropriate congressional committees regarding the marginalization of Pacific Islands students in the awarding of Fulbright Scholarships. (Sec. 1427) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the governments and peoples of Turkey and the newly independent states of the Caspian Sea region should be congratulated for the successful completion of the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline; (2) U.S. support for the independence and economic development of the newly independent states of the Caspian Sea region should be reaffirmed; and (3) projects should be encouraged that develop the east-west energy transportation corridor between the newly independent states of the Caspian Sea region and Europe, and that advance U.S. strategic goals. (Sec. 1428) Expresses the sense of Congress that Poland should develop a final and nondiscriminatory settlement for those individuals who had their private property seized and confiscated by the Nazis during World War II or by the Communist Polish government after the war. (Sec. 1429) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the government of the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire and the government of the Republic of Ghana should be commended for their steps to address the situation of child labor in the cocoa sector, and should consider child labor and forced labor issues top priorities; (2) such governments, the chocolate industry, and nongovernmental organizations should continue their efforts to develop and implement a system to monitor child labor in the cocoa industry; and (3) the Department should assist such governments in preventing the trafficking of persons into the cocoa fields and other industries in West Africa. (Sec. 1430) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) Iraqi Kurds should be commended for their many contributions and sacrifices made in the cause of creating a democratic Iraq; and (2) the Iraqi Transitional Government and the Kurdistan Regional Government are expected to adhere to the highest standards of democratic governance, including through enforcement of full equality and rights for all religious and ethnic minorities, such as Assyrians and Turcomans. (Sec. 1431) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the Secretary should strengthen the 2003 Proliferation Security Initiative by placing particular emphasis on including non-NATO countries; and (2) the United States should seek an international instrument to enhance international cooperation regarding the interdiction, seizure, and impoundment in international waters and airspace of illicit shipments of weapons of mass destruction. (Sec. 1432) Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should implement standards to improve the security of nuclear weapons and materials. (Sec. 1433) Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should assist the International Criminal Court to bring to justice persons accused of genocide, war crimes, or crimes against humanity in Darfur, Sudan, provided that legally binding assurances have been received from the U.N. Security Council or the Court that no current or former U.S. official, employee (including any contractor), armed forces member, or U.S. national will be subject to Court prosecution in connection with these efforts. (Sec. 1434) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) all countries that host satellite companies that broadcast al-Manar television (owned by Hezbollah), on whose territory al-Manar may be viewed over media subject to government regulation, or where advertising or other financial support for al-Manar originates, should suppress al-Manar's terroristic programming; and (2) the Arab States Broadcasting Union should revoke al-Manar's membership status because of al-Manar's promotion of hatred and incitement to violence, including suicide bombings, directed toward Americans, Israelis, and Jews. (Sec. 1435) Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should transmit to the appropriate congressional committees as soon as possible the plan to provide for a stable and secure government of Iraq and an Iraqi military and police force that will allow the U.S. military presence in Iraq to be diminished. (Sec. 1436) Expresses the sense of the Congress that the government of Ethiopia should account for, compensate, or return to U.S. citizens and entities property that has been nationalized or otherwise seized by the government of Ethiopia in contravention of international law. (Sec. 1437) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the comments by Chinese General Zhu Chenghu advocating the use of nuclear weapons against the United States are both damaging to U.S.-China relations and a violation of China's commitment to resolve its differences with Taiwan peacefully; and (2) the government of China should renounce the use of force against Taiwan, disavow General Zhu's statements, and relieve General Zhu from his command. (Sec. 1438) Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the capture, detention, and interrogation of international terrorists are essential to the successful prosecution of the Global War on Terrorism and to defense of the United States, its citizens, and its coalition partners from future terrorist attacks; (2) the detention and lawful, humane interrogation by the United States of detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, is essential to the defense of the United States and its coalition partners and to the successful prosecution of the Global War on Terrorism; and (3) the detention facilities and interrogations at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, play an essential role in U.S. security and should not be closed or ended while the United States is waging the Global War of Terrorism.
